Kelly's goal of creating a coming-of-age story set in the 1980s with an emphasis on suburban life.
The New York Times observed the influence of John Hughes' style on Kelly's work, specifically in relation to the portrayal of ineffective adults and coming-of-age themes.
Kelly's description of his script as 'an amusing and poignant recollection of suburban America in the Reagan era.'

Kelly's idea for resolving the mystery of the falling object by involving a plane from another dimension.

node_2: concept of time travel and alternate universes in kelly's script
edge: Kelly based his ideas for time travel and alternate dimensions on Stephen Hawking's book, A Brief History of Time.
Kelly felt pressured to make the setting more contemporary, but could not figure out how to make the story work in such a setting and retained the original setting of 1988.
Kelly got ideas for Donnie's experiences of paranoid schizophrenia from researching the topic online.
After two more drafts were written, Kelly finalised a 128-page script based on his original first draft that was between 145–150 pages.

Kelly felt that had he clarified the film's ending any further, 'the film would collapse under its own pretension', and credited McKittrick, Juvonen, and Gyllenhaal for not letting there be one simple answer to the plot.
The use of the word 'fuck-ass' in the Darko family dinner scene is a direct reference to Kelly's film school friends who frequently used this insult during their exchanges.

Initially, Frank was supposed to be a rabbit in the movie. While the exact origin of the character is unclear, Kelly has mentioned that it might have been inspired by his long-standing fascination with Richard Adams' novel Watership Down.

According to Kelly, Graham Greene was supposed to be taught in Karen's English class after the school had censored it from her curriculum. However, this subplot was eventually cut from the theatrical version.
Kelly's childhood town of Midlothian, Virginia is connected to a local woman called Grandma Death, who would frequently open and close her mailbox while standing by the road.
Kelly almost ran over a homeless person while driving in his childhood town of Midlothian, Virginia. This experience has been incorporated into the narrative.
In the context, Karen had arguments with her school teachers over the curriculum, which is a part of the narrative that Kelly has included in his work.
According to Kelly himself, there is 'plenty of me' in Donnie's character.
Kelly knew that the film's complicated story would be difficult to pitch to producers without a script, so he had producers read it first before discussing it with them further.
Kelly had producers read the film's complicated story first before discussing it with them further.
While pitching the script, Kelly and McKittrick insisted that Kelly direct the film, which hindered its chances at being picked up.
Kelly directed Donnie Darko.
Kelly recalled 1999 being a year of 'meeting after meeting'.
Donnie Darko was 'the challenging script in town' that everybody wanted to make, but was too afraid.'
agents John Campisi and Rob Paris from Creative Artists Agency showed interest in Kelly's script, greatly boosting the chances of having the film made.

In early 2000, actor Jason Schwartzman expressed an interest in the script and agreed to play the character Donnie, which legitimized the director as his decision sparked renewed interest in the project.
The development of the script progressed in early 2000, and Jason Schwartzman's involvement as Donnie was a significant moment in this process.
In early 2000, when Jason Schwartzman expressed an interest in the script and agreed to play as Donnie, Pandora Cinema offered a $2.5 million production budget.
In March 2000 on the set of Charlie's Angels, actress Drew Barrymore, who co-owned Flower Films, liked the script and wanted to play as Karen.
Drew Barrymore's involvement in the project through her production company Flower Films led to a meeting between Kelly, McKittrick, and Barrymore in March 2000.
Drew Barrymore's decision to play as Karen led to Flower Films increasing the production budget to $4.5 million, which helped to further the development progress of the project.

node_2: interactive experience and marketing tool for the film donnie darko
edge: The official Donnie Darko website, donniedarko.com, which can still be found at http://archive.hi-res.net/donniedarko/ Archived April 16, 2017, at the Wayback Machine is an interactive experience and marketing tool for the film made by Hi-ReS!, a digital marketing firm.

The Donnie Darko website is riddled with puzzles and secrets and contains never-before-seen information about the universe of the film, including information about the fate of many of the characters after the film ends.

node_2: validity as a narrative in and of itself
edge: James Beck has commented on the website's validity as a narrative in and of itself due to the website's introduction of new content while reinforcing themes from the movie like fluidity of time, exemplified by the website's lack of concern for the chronology of the movie.

Beck further argues that the Donnie Darko website differs from most other promotional websites in that it treats the user not as an outside viewer, but rather as someone within the universe of the film, creating an experience rather than an advertisement.

The official Donnie Darko website, donniedarko.com, which can still be found at http://archive.hi-res.net/donniedarko/ Archived April 16, 2017, at the Wayback Machine is an interactive experience and marketing tool for the film Donnie Darko made by Hi-ReS!, a digital marketing firm.

The terms 'Tangent Universe' and 'Primary Universe' refer to two distinct universes, with the former being a part of the latter. This relationship is established through the concept of 'ensurance trap', which forces the Living, who are more aware than those in the Tangent Universe but less so than those setting the trap, to save the Primary Universe by traveling through time.

Both 'Frank' and 'Gretchen' are individuals who reside within the Tangent Universe and possess heightened awareness compared to those living in that universe. This is evident from their ability to travel through time.
Donnie Darko is Richard Kelly's debut feature.
Donnie Darko is a heady blend of science fiction and teen angst, according to Andrew Johnson in Us Weekly.
Donnie Darko is a heady blend of science fiction, spirituality, and teen angst, according to Andrew Johnson in Us Weekly.

The review aggregator website Rotten Tomatoes reported that 87% of critics gave the film a positive review based on 119 reviews, with an average rating of 7.6/10. The site's critics consensus reads, 'Richard Kelly's debut feature Donnie Darko is a daring, original vision, packed with jarring ideas and intelligence and featuring a remarkable performance from Jake Gyllenhaal as the troubled title character.'
Some critics have described Donnie Darko as a 1970s time-travel movie set in the present day.
Donnie Darko is considered to be a cult film.
Donnie Darko is a mind-bending movie, according to Roger Ebert (for the director's cut).
Roger Ebert gave the director's cut of Donnie Darko three stars out of four, whereas he gave the theatrical version two and a half stars out of four.
